29.12.text: Hello, another bout of intellectual snowballs lies ahead of us

32.60.text: with two more teams of distinguished alumni preparing

35.84.text: to battle it out for a place in the semifinals.

38.56.text: We've now played four of the seven first-round matches

42.32.text: and as only the four teams with the highest winning scores

45.40.text: will go through, we already know that the University of Kent

48.56.text: will definitely appear again, and a score of 190 or more

51.88.text: will guarantee that tonight's winners do so too.

55.12.text: Now, Edinburgh University is represented first

58.04.text: by a scientist whose specialism is

60.24.text: the overlap between genetics and evolution.

63.08.text: He's also a world expert on the genetics of snails,

66.28.text: with which we apparently share a distant ancestry,

69.60.text: a revelation that on reflection isn't quite as surprising

73.76.text: With him, an academic and broadcaster,

76.52.text: who's researched landscape evolution in Australia, Africa

79.08.text: and Antarctica. More recently, alongside her present role

82.48.text: in Edinburgh, she's appeared on TV series such as Coast,

86.28.text: Rough Science and The Nature Of Britain.

95.72.text: and the Bletchley Circle, as well as the BAFTA-award-winning comedy

99.60.text: The Detectorists, and films such as Salmon Fishing In The Yemen.

117.36.text: for which she's been a commissioning editor
